name: treatment of coal gas, in power plant | electricity, high voltage | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/5350/documentation

Activity represents electricity production from coal gas treatment in power plants. Based on European data.;This dataset represents the treatment of coke oven gas (coal gas) in an unspecified gas power plant with high voltage electricity and heat as by-product in Turkey in 2012.;According to IEA (2008), coke oven gas is obtained as a by-product of solid fuel carbonisation and gasification operations carried out by coke producers and iron and steel plants not connected with gas works and municipal gas plants.;The efficiency calculations are based on IEA/OECD statistics (fuel inputs, electricity produced). No exergy correction could be made due to incomplete data (see ecoinvent report "Erdgas" p. 128 for details).;Water is used for wet cooling and as feed water in the steam circuit. In this dataset, 100% wet cooling and no once-through cooling is assumed.  ;EMISSIONS:;Emission data have partly been overtaken from a dataset representing the production of electricity in a natural gas power plant. Data have partly been adapted to the different composition of natural gas and coal gas (see tab. 11.16 in ecoinvent report "Erdgas").;Different sources served as basis for assumption of average emissions. Where possible, the most recent sources were taken into account, whereas older sources were taken in order to determine the remaining data gaps. The emissions have been fixed for the former UCTE region* and have been overtaken as such for all countries without value adaptation (adaptation of the uncertainty). See ecoinvent report "Erdgas" given as main source for details (Tab. 11.15 and tab. 11.17). In the following a short overview:; - Emissions of NOx, CO, CO2, SO2, particles, N2O and CH4 are mainly taken from CORINAIR 2001, Rentz et al. 2002, and Swedish EPA 2000 (see tab. 11.17) and are basically valid for European countries.;-	NOx emissions are a major challenge in natural gas power plants. With rising temperature, emissions also rise; band widths of NOx emissions in literature are correspondingly large. There are several methods to diminish these emissions.;-	CO is a result of incomplete burning. For economic and technical reasons, plant combustion is optimized and CO emissions are low. ;-	CO2 and SO2 emissions are depending on the composition of the used fuel.;Coal gas can have very different sulfur contents and is washed out. Efficiency of sulfur removal is assumed to reach 90%. ;-	Organic compound emissions are estimated on the basis of EPA 1998. ;-	Particles are assumed to be smaller than 2.5 micro-m;Sources:;EMEP/CORINAIR 2001: Joint EMEP/CORINAIR Atmospheric Emission Inventory Guidebook, Third Edition. Copenhagen: European Environment Agency, 2001. http://reports.eea.eu.int/technical_report_2001_3/en.;Rentz O., Karl U., Peter H. (2002). Ermittlung und Evaluierung von Emissionsfaktoren für Feuerungsanlagen in Deutschland für die Jahre 1995, 2000 und 2010. Deutsch- Französisches Institut für Umweltforschung, Uni Karsruhe. Endbericht. Im Auftrag des Umweltbundesamtes. Forschungsbericht 299 43 142. Umweltbundesamt. Berlin.;Swedish EPA (2000) Emission Factors. Swedish Environmental Protection Agency.;IEA/OECD. 2008. Coal information 2008. International Energy Agency (IEA), Paris Cedex (FR);*former UCTE: Union for the Coordination of the Transmission of Electricity, since 2009 replaced by ENTSO-E European Network of Transmission System Operators for Electricity.

From the coal gas ready to be treated in a gas power plant and from the gas power plant ready to produce electricity.

This treatment activity ends with 1MJ of coal gas treated in a power plant. 

This dataset includes:
 - the emissions from burning
 - all operation and maintenance activities and materials of the power plants.
 - Cooling: It is a assumed that all plants use wet cooling with a cooling tower. No cooling tower is included in this dataset (will be implemented in future versions)

This dataset doesn"t include 
 - raw materials extraction, decommissioning and waste treatment as these activities are already included in the infrastructure datasets.
 - transformation of the by-product electricity.
category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/351:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution/3510:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution
tags: Sector: Electricity; Waste Treatment & Recycling; Heat

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The annual production volume is valid for the year 2012.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: A natural gas power plant with a capacity of 100 MW is taken as power plant infrastructure.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription:
Emission data partly taken over from natural gas power plants.
Emission data partly from old references.
A natural gas power plant is taken as infrastructure input.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. 1kWh = 3.6 MJ

exchanges.description:
Literature value/calculated value. Value overtaken from the dataset of natural gas burned in a normal power plant (electricity production, natural gas, GLO 2008). 

Emissions when burning 1MJ of natural gas. Weighted average with electricity production data (Itten&Frischknecht 2012) and emission values of 11 countries 
(AT, BE, DE, ES, FR, GB, IT, JP, LU, NL, US) (Faist Emmenegger et al. 2007, JP and US in the appendix) 
Country emissions values estimate from range of values from different references. See Tab. 11.19, p. 138 in Faist Emmenegger et al. 2007.

Source: 
Itten R. and Frischknecht R. (2012) Life Cycle Inventories of Electricity Mixes and Grid. ESU-services Ltd., Uster, Switzerland.

exchanges.description: Literature value/assumption. Feed water for the steam circuit lost when burning 1MJ of coal gas. Röder et al. 2007, Tab. 9.65 and Tab. 9.66, p. 160f. Faist Emmenegger et al. 2007 state that there have been nearly no information on water use in coal gas power plants and therefore neglected the water use. For consistency reasons, here it is assumed a certain water use also for the treatment of coal gas.
